urn:contentItem:5S35-1S81-DY0W-405P-00000-00Facebook's Zuckerberg takes grilling on the Hill; Facebook and big tech under fire; Mueller closes in on Trump's personal life; Does America really care about Stormy?; War Drums: DC and media hungry for Syria strike; The left's response on Syria: Shut up and obey; Syria Chemical Attack: We need answers first; Women's March angry at Backpage shutdown2018-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisFacebook's Zuckerberg takes grilling on the Hill; Facebook and big tech under fire; Mueller closes in on Trump's personal life; Does America really care about Stormy?; War Drums: DC and media hungry for Syria strike; The left's response on Syria: Shut up and obey; Syria Chemical Attack: We need answers first; Women's March angry at Backpage shutdownLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

Robert Mueller's investigation, you'll remember, was supposed to be about Russian collusion, the hacking of our election.

Obviously, there's a new goal now. What is it? In a minute, Brit Hume and Professor Jonathan Turley join us to spell that out.

But, first, Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg spent hours on Capitol Hill today taking questions from senators about Facebook's role in the 2016 election and in American society more generally. We'll talk to one of the senators who was there and spoke to Zuckerberg and more broadly what it meant.

But, first, Brett Larson, an anchor at "Fox News Headlines 24/7", who covers tech for our show, has the big moments from today. Brett?

BRETT LARSON, FOX NEWS ANCHOR, "FOX NEWS HEADLINES 24/7": It was quite the day, Tucker. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg checked in with Congress today for day one of hearings.

And we learned a little bit about the inner workings of the social media giant. One thing we heard repeatedly was exactly what Facebook is and is not.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZUCKERBERG, FACEBOOK CEO: What you think of as the Facebook service, everyone has control every single time that they go to share that, they can delete that data anytime they want, full control for the majority of the data.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: Sharing everything? Not so much.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. DICK DURBIN (D), ILLINOIS: Mr. Zuckerberg, would you be comfortable sharing with us the name of the hotel you stayed in last night?

ZUCKERBERG: No.

DURBIN: I think that might be what this is all about. Your right to privacy, the limits of your right to privacy, and how much you give away.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: But with 2.2 billion users and in the wake of concerns about more than 80 million users having their data stolen by political consulting firm, Cambridge Analytica, is Facebook your only choice?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: If I buy a Ford and it doesn't work well and I don't like it, I can buy a Chevy. If I'm upset with Facebook, what's the equivalent product that I can go sign up for?

ZUCKERBERG: The second category that I was going to talk about -

GRAHAM: I'm not talking about categories. I'm talking about, is there real competition you face? You don't think you have a monopoly?

ZUCKERBERG: It certainly doesn't feel like that to me.

GRAHAM: OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: There is also concerns, Tucker, about First Amendment rights and just what control the social media giant has over what you see, say, and share.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. TED CRUZ (R), TEXAS: You say that you have 15,000 to 20,000 people working on security and content review. Do you know the political orientation of those 15,000 to 20,000 people engaged in content review?

ZUCKERBERG: No, senator. We do not generally ask people about their political orientation when they're joining the company.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: Sen. Ben Sasse asked a similar question about censorship on the site and CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the speech they censor is any time someone pushes to hurt others. Sen. Sasse was also concerned about addiction to the social media site.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BEN SASSE (R), NEBRASKA: As a dad, do you worry about social media addiction as a problem for America's teens?

ZUCKERBERG: Well, my hope is that we can be idealistic, but have a broad view of our responsibility.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LARSON: And, Tucker, we will get more from Zuckerberg tomorrow when he sits down for day two. He's certainly been very frank in his responses and a little obtuse about specifics, which made the lack of understanding of exactly how Facebook works and our understanding of it very clear.

CARLSON: Thanks for that, Brett. Appreciate it. Sen. John Kennedy of Louisiana was one of the many senators who spoke to Zuckerberg today. Here's part of it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA: Here's what everybody's been trying to tell you today. And I say this gently. Your user agreement sucks. I'm going to suggest to you that you go back home and rewrite it. And tell your $1200 an hour lawyers - no disrespect; they're good - but tell them you want it written in English.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Sen. Kennedy joins us tonight. Senator, thanks for coming on.

SEN. JOHN KENNEDY (R), LOUISIANA: You bet.

CARLSON: What was the point of this hearing there? What laws are you all considering to constrain Facebook?

KENNEDY: Tucker, I was mildly disappointed with the hearing. I mean, I wanted the point to be - I wanted Mr. Zuckerberg to step up to the plate and say, look - three words - I'm on it. I get it. It can be fixed. I'm going to fix it. And we'll do it together. That's not what I heard. I just didn't feel like we connected with Mr. Zuckerberg today.

I mean, look, Facebook is an extraordinary company. It's done magical things, but it's clear that the digital promised land has some minefields in it. One is the privacy issue; the other is the propaganda.

And I don't want to have to vote to regulate Facebook, but, my God, I will unless they're willing to step up to the plate and address those two issues. I think they can; I hope they can. If they can't, we've got a bigger problem than just what we talked about today.

CARLSON: So, here you've got the biggest provider of news in the United States with far more power than William Randolph I ever had with a long and proven track record of censorship in this country and other countries, with the power to change election results.

You don't think that's enough of a threat right there to act?

KENNEDY: Well, I think that's a very important issue. Sen. Cruz and Sen. Sasse made that point. I ran out of time. I wanted to make that point.

And I think it's true. Poison is being spread on social media. OK. What's poison? Define poison.

And, look, I wanted - a lot of our Democratic friends have made a big deal about, well, Cambridge Analytica may work with President Trump. I wanted to ask Mr. Zuckerberg today about this statement that was made by somebody - a Ms. Carol Davidson from President Obama's election campaign in 2012.

This is what she says. She ran media analytics for the president. She said, "Facebook was very candid that they allowed us to do things they wouldn't have allowed someone else to do because they were on our side."

CARLSON: Right.

KENNEDY: I wanted to ask if that's an accurate statement, but I ran out of time.

CARLSON: Finally, the Congress would have really uniquely the ability to get this under control, if you think that too much power is vested in one company and they're, in effect, enemies of the First Amendment.

I know Republicans don't like to regulate things, but do you think we're approaching a point where - for the good of the public - that may need to be done?

KENNEDY: I don't think we're there yet, but I think a lot of it depends on how Mr. Zuckerberg reacts to this.

I'll say it again. There are two issues. One is a privacy problem. The other is a propaganda problem. And the issue there is how do we solve it without impinging on people's First Amendment rights?

Now, that's a tough one.

CARLSON: It is a tough one.

KENNEDY: And I want to be assured. Didn't get it today. Maybe we'll get it in the second round that Facebook is not politically biased one way or the other.

I don't want him pitching for the Republicans. I don't want him pitching for the Democrats either.

CARLSON: Yes. Well, they are. Senator, thank you. Great to see you.

KENNEDY: You bet, Tucker.

CARLSON: For more discussion of what happened today, Dave Maney is a tech entrepreneur and a fan of Facebook, Roger McNamee who was one of Facebook's first investors and now a critic sometimes of the company. Both of them join us.

So, Roger, first to you. The head of Facebook Mark Zuckerberg said today that he and the company are happy to censor hate speech, but was unclear exactly on what hate speech is. And then, suggested that maybe artificial intelligence will settle that question.

If you care about freedom of speech, does that make you uncomfortable?

ROGER MCNAMEE, ZUCKERBERG'S FORMER MENTOR: I think the whole thing makes me uncomfortable, Tucker.

I think the fundamental issue we've got here is its business model is based on inflammatory emotions - anger and fear.

And once you build a business model on that, it's really - the genie is out of the bottle and there's no way to put it back in. And Facebook has shown itself to be less than good at managing the dialogue on its site.

And as you pointed out, they are absolutely editing everything. There are a million different things they could show me at any moment in time. They pick the 20 that serve their business model best.

And quite clearly, they have failed on that, precisely as Sen. Kennedy just described.

CARLSON: Dave, we had a researcher on, a psychologist recently called Robert Epstein and he's taken a look at a bunch of different tech companies.

And he said specifically about Facebook, if Mark Zuckerberg had sent a targeted message to people identified on Facebook as Hillary voters and encouraged them to vote, he estimates it could have changed the vote total by 450,000 on election day 2016 and changed the course of the election.

That's a lot of power for one media company to have. Even if you are for Mark Zuckerberg's political views, should any company have the ability to change election outcomes the way Facebook does?

DAVE MANEY, TECH ENTREPRENEUR: I think you're giving him too much credit. First of all, I'm not a fan of that political worldview. I am a fan of free enterprise and letting them do what they will.

I mean, by that standard, how many people vote does "The New York Times" editorial choosing a candidate or anybody else is making influence?

So, I'm very wary of the Facebook site as a user. But this discussion about should we censor them and knock-back their political influence and are they a gigantic monopoly, I mean, I think that's crazy.

CARLSON: But they're literally a monopoly.

MANEY: They're not a monopoly, Tucker.

CARLSON: They are. They are actually because I know the numbers. I've worked in (INAUDIBLE) a lot for eight years.

Let me just give you the following number. So, Facebook and Google control over 90 percent of digital ads. So, that means if you run news or anything else that's ad supported online, you're beholden to them. They control the market completely. Why is that not a monopoly?

MANEY: If you want to say it's a monopoly for digital ads, that's fine. If you want to say it's a monopoly for political content, it's not.

CARLSON: But hold on. Digital ads are what supports all online news coverage apart from the non-profits. That's the whole point. You control the ads, you control the company.

MANEY: Tucker, are you worried about a monopoly in the digital ad business or are you worried about a concentration of political power?

CARLSON: Well, I don't think there's a distinction between those two things. I'm worried that, in the addition to both, by the total inability of the Congress to respond to a looming threat to its own legitimacy from Facebook and Google. Roger, am I being insane here? I don't think that I am.

MCNAMEE: Tucker, I'm on your side on this issue because, at the end of the day, the problem we have here is a massive concentration of power. And that concentration of power is in the hands of people who preserve the rights of the First Amendment for their corporation, but they tend to overlook the First Amendment rights of the people who are the users of the sites.

And in that process, I mean, what we have is these things that are global, they are influencing democracy all around the world and we can't find a single example of them influencing it for the better.

And I'm with the Sen. Kennedy. This thing has gone on both sides. We've seen massive abuses of Facebook on both sides of this thing. And It doesn't look good either way.

And we need to reduce Facebook's influence, so that we don't have it determining the outcome of any election, whether it's 2012, 2016, 2018, or 2020.

CARLSON: Well, I think that's right because, in the end, Dave, this is not an American company or, more precisely, a company that sees itself as an American company. I would argue that, in effect, is, but they don't see that. Google doesn't either. They're companies of the world.

And yet, they have more influence potentially over our voting patterns than Russia or China or any other government. So, like, why wouldn't that be a threat to democracy?

MCNAMEE: And the worst part of it, Tucker, is they behave as though they don't have any influence; and as a result, bad actors have been able to manipulate the system, essentially undefended.

And to David, my simple point here is that, having watched this company from its earliest days, it has evolved into something very different than it started out as. And I too am a believer in free enterprise, but I'm a bigger believer in democracy and I don't believe any company's rights come before the rights of the people of the United States.

CARLSON: So, David, I'm going to let you sum it up. Does any of this bother you? I get that you're for free enterprise. I admire that. But does any of this bother you at all?

MANEY: I largely stopped using the app in January when I went through their latest news revision to decide what I could see and not see. But that doesn't mean that I believe that Sen. Kennedy or those other knuckleheads down there today in that hearing, which gives - I'd say it was a goat rodeo, but that's unfair to goat rodeos.

Like, you can't let those people make those decisions. Consumers have to make those decisions. And your assertion that it's an unbreakable monopoly, it's just not.

CARLSON: Well, it's not only unbreakable, it's growing in its part. Anyway, thank you both. We're out of time sadly. Appreciate it.

Tonight, in just the past 12 minutes, we've seen evidence that two other cable networks are colluding with "The New York Times" to put out negative stories on the Trump administration. Sort of.

Our proof and both Brit Hume and Professor Jonathan Turley coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: "CNN", "MSNBC", and "The New York Times" are working together tonight to push a new story about the Trump administration.

At the top of the hour, "MSNBC" put on Maggie Haberman. "CNN" put on Michael Schmidt. Those two are both "Times" reporters. And they co- authored a piece in that newspaper, saying that Donald Trump attempted to fire Robert Mueller in December. Mueller is still there, of course.

The Mueller investigation, you'll remember, was officially created to uncover Russian hacking into the American democracy because they hacked our democracy.

But that's not what it is anymore. It is now an all-purpose probe into the president, his personal and financial life. It's designed to make us feel safer. I hope you feel safer.

Yesterday, FBI agents raided the office of Michael Cohen. That's the president's personal lawyer, apparently looking for evidence about payments to Stormy Daniels, the porn star who is not from Russia and who did not hack our election in any case.

Over on "MSNBC", Steve Schmidt noted that the men who wrote the constitution would be thrilled by this. They always hated the Bill of Rights, those guys.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE SCHMIDT, "THE NEW YORK TIMES" CORRESPONDENT: If you listen closely tonight, you can hear the faint applause from heaven of this country's founding fathers who bequeathed to us a nation where the rule of law is supreme. We are a nation of laws.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Yes. The founders wanted to know, did the money go to Stormy Daniels? What happened to Stormy Daniels?

Jonathan Turley is a professor at George Washington University's School of Law and he joins us tonight.

So, I think, professor, you were one of the trustworthy people in this conversation. I don't even know what your politics are. I don't think we even agree politically, but whatever. I trust your legal views.

What do you make of this raid on the president's lawyer's offices?

JONATHAN TURLEY, GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF LAW PROFESSOR: Well, part of this is of Cohen's making, in the sense that Cohen tends to blur his relationships between being a lawyer, a fixer and a business partner.

That's dangerous under any circumstances, but it's particularly dangerous if you're going to invoke the attorney-client attorney privilege because, first, you have to prove that you're acting like an attorney.

And he may have trouble with that. When you look at the Stormy Daniels agreement, it's still not clear what role he's playing there, whether he's this company he created, whether he's Trump's lawyer, that's going to come back to haunt him and haunt the president when they say some of this stuff should remain confidential.

But I think the president is right, in a sense that whenever you have a raid on an attorney's office, it should raise very troubling concerns for everyone.

I mean, this is a serious problem when someone can't rely on their attorney.

CARLSON: So, is the core potential violation here that the payments to Stormy Daniels - Ms. Daniels, we'll call her - were some form of campaign finance violations?

TURLEY: Well, actually, that is strengthening with some of the statements made publicly. When the president said, I didn't know anything about this payment, it sounds a lot like what's called an in-kind campaign contribution.

And that's what John Edwards was charged with and prosecuted for. He ultimately was not convicted of that. But, yes, they could make a case like that.

But, supposedly, the warrant covers everything from Stormy Daniels to taxi medallions. And there's a lot in between.

CARLSON: Is there any indication that Stormy Daniels was working with Russian agents to influence the outcome of the election, that she was herself part of the hacking of our democracy?

TURLEY: Well, I'm not familiar with all of her movies, but no. But, no, I'm not familiar with -

CARLSON: OK. So, I guess, we can say that the nature of the investigation has changed profoundly.

TURLEY: Oh, absolutely. Now, there's no question that this is a far off the mark. So was Manafort.

What's actually sort of fascinating about this is that Rod Rosenstein didn't have much of a problem when Mueller came to him and said I want to expand Manafort's investigation to include stuff that occurred years before and were not connected to the campaign.

Some of this stuff is actually closer, and yet Rosenstein said I want the southern district to do this.

CARLSON: Could Rosenstein have said, "No, that's not the original charter of this, that's not the point of this investigation?

TURLEY: He could have, but it gets a little bit tough. If Mueller came to him and said, "Look, we have evidence of crime that we have uncovered," it's hard not to give that to a prosecutor to look at.

We don't know what was shown to Rod Rosenstein. And that's part of the problem.

CARLSON: I think what you're saying is you would have to be either dumb or an active drug user to allow an independent counsel investigation to start.

TURLEY: Well, I think that - look, this is one of those things where it's easy to unleash the dogs of war. It's harder to get them back.

CARLSON: Yes. I know.

TURLEY: And a special counsel is a torpedo in the water, to use another metaphor. And he's still there.

And what's interesting about this move is that they haven't just expanded the investigation, they've expanded the prosecutors.

So, now, even if the president moved against Rosenstein, moved against Mueller, it wouldn't necessarily stop with the southern district.

CARLSON: Yes. Thank you for that. Professor Jonathan Turley, appreciate it.

Democrats are gearing up for an impeachment push against the president. What's the point of that and what will the outcome of it be, assuming they take back the House in the midterm? Brit Hume joins us next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: With all of this turmoil, particularly this last week, has the president at any time thought about stepping down before or now?

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDER, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: No. And I think that's an absolutely ridiculous question.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well, nobody can quite in the light of day tell you why the Stormy Daniels story is so significant, but clearly it is judging by the air time it gets. It's more important than the looming war in Syria, more important than the fact our economy is being eclipsed by China, more important than the vanishing American middle class or the tens of thousands who will die of drug ODs this year.

In fact, it matters so much that President Trump should consider leaving office over it. Does anyone who doesn't work in the media believe that?

Brit Hume is our senior political analyst here at Fox and he joins us tonight. So, Brit - and maybe I'm blinded by my reflexive revulsion about this story, but is it? In the scheme of stories concerning the world is on fire and changing faster than we can keep up with, is the Stormy Daniels story as significant as the airtime it's getting, do you think?

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Of course, it's not.

CARLSON: Thank you.

HUME: The big problem with the story from the start has been this. It doesn't tell us anything about Donald Trump that we didn't already know or should have known.

Indeed, this story itself came out - at least a piece of it that he had this liaison with her came out before the election.

Americans who voted for and against Donald Trump knew, or should have known, that he was a habitual philanderer. He had made a great public spectacle of it in the past, that he was a man with a taste for flashy women.

The story was entirely credible and remains so to this day. And the fact that he denies is a detail. I don't think most of the people who are for him think that his denial is true, but it simply doesn't rise to the kind of level you're talking about here unless you want to take very seriously the possibility that the money paid to keep her from blurting all this out sooner was a campaign contribution that well exceeded the proper limits for campaign contributions.

That is about as big as you can get it to be as far as we know.

CARLSON: That seems like a pretty tenuous connection to news. Just me. By the way, the other channels have covered this exclusively since we started 28 minutes ago. I mean, that's all they've covered for this hour so far.

HUME: Well, I think there's a lot of excitement about the search of the Cohen offices and so on, but the question that still you have to answer here is what really is the underlying crime and does it rise to the level of something for purposes of impeachment or as the questioner at the briefing said the possibility that Trump would resign.

That's an interesting question, of course, Tucker. Does anything about Trump's behavior in reaction to any of this suggest that this is a man contemplating quitting?

CARLSON: No!

HUME: I would say, obviously, palpably not.

CARLSON: I'm not sure that he or anyone in the White House fully understands what would happen if Democrats take the House this fall as many polls suggest they will.

It seems like the very top of their agenda will be impeaching President Trump. That's what their voters want.

Yesterday, Congressman Beto O'Rourke of Texas, who is running against Cruz in the Senate race, said he would vote to impeach Trump, although he acknowledged it wouldn't make sense to do it right now.

But Democratic voters want impeachment. Do you think Democratic members, if they take control of the House, can do anything but start an impeachment?

HUME: I think there'll be moves in that direction. Of course, the last time this was done, in the case of Bill Clinton and the judges there were among other perjury and obstruction of justice that were pretty thoroughly documented - he had, obviously, lied to a grand jury. They did it.

They impeached him in the House and he was not anywhere near convicted in the Senate and he ended up leaving office in something like a blaze of glory and it kind of backfired politically on the Republicans. And Democratic politicians - those in the House of Representatives - might be given some pause by how all that turned out.

But you're right about the base. The Democratic base cannot the stand the ground that Trump walks on. They want him out and they want him impeached and they want their members to be part of the resistance.

Little Mr. O'Rourke running against Ted Cruz in Texas seemed a little confused about how impeachment works because he's running for the Senate and the Senate doesn't vote to impeach. The House votes to impeach. The Senate votes on whether or not to convict.

But that aside, his sentiments reflect that of many Democrats. And I think there will be a move to do it if, in fact, they get control of the House. How well it will work out for them politically remains to be seen.

CARLSON: It does remain to be seen. Brit Hume, thanks as always. Great to see you.

HUME: You bet.

CARLSON: Well, all the geniuses here in Washington are unanimous on this question. We must attack Syria and anyone who asks questions about why we must attack Syria is, obviously, by definition, working for Vladimir Putin.

How has this happened? How has almost everybody in power lined up behind yet another military intervention? Is the public crying out for one? Glenn Greenwald has watched this fairly carefully and he joins us next with an answer.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Well, virtually, all of official Washington - Republicans and Democrats - have united behind the idea that the United States has a moral obligation to go deeper into war in Syria.

We already have thousands of troops in Syria, but you wouldn't know it from watching the other Robert Mueller based channels. They're all Stormy Daniels all the time. But it's true we do.

And one American soldier had already died in Syria. We've killed hundreds of Russian citizens so far there and lobbed in a serious of cruise missiles. But that's not enough, the pundits say. We need a real war, something big and deadly, primarily to avenge the Syrian President Assad's poison gas attack on his own citizens over the weekend.

Here is some of the growing consensus on that.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GRAHAM: Assad and his inner circle should be considered war criminals, legitimate military targets. If you have the opportunity to take him out, you should.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's very clear to me that this president, after using such rhetoric on Sunday, has to take stronger military action than we did last year.

REP. JIM HINES (D), HOUSE INTELLIGENCE COMMITTEE: We have a leader who is now a war criminal supported by the Iranians and the Russians. That demands a strong and risky response.

If the West won't stand up when a leader uses gas multiple times against his own people, we live in a very dangerous world.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So, that's the consensus. Last night, we asked the obvious questions about it. Before we go to war, are we sure all of this is real? Do we really know that Assad was behind the gas attack?

It's not a defense of Assad, but it's an obvious question. How could we know that conclusively so soon after the attack happened? We didn't have any Americans on the ground? And why would Assad do that given the certainty it would hurt his own interests?

And while we're on the subject, by the way, why is a war in Syria a good idea for the United States in the first place? How would it make us safer, happier, more prosperous?

Those seem like reasonable questions to us. In fact, the exact questions you'd want your policymakers to ask. But, no, they're not asking them. And they're offended to hear them.

The first person we asked those questions to, Republican Senator Roger Wicker of Mississippi implied that we were somehow allied with Vladimir Putin just for asking. Other than that, Wicker had no answers at all. It was embarrassing and he didn't seem embarrassed at all.

Others just denounced us right off the top. Jennifer Rubin of "The Washington Post" tweeted this, "He is insane," meaning me. "Fox is not a news organization. That is all."

Noah Rothman of "Commentary" called the show "nothing less than undiluted Russian propaganda.

Seth Mandel of "The New York Post" summarized the criticism perfectly when he tweeted this, "shut the F up."

These are journalists, by the way. No explanation. Of course, shutting the F up is the whole point of tweets like that. They want you to be quiet. They want you to do what you're told. No more questions, shut up and obey. There's no chance of that, though. Sorry.

Glenn Greenwald has been following all of this. He's a founding editor at "The Intercept" and he joins us tonight. So, Glenn, leaving aside the real question of how you should respond to Syria and is it a threat to the world order and to us and to its neighbors, I think those are all fair questions, but why the universal attempt in the media here in this country - left and right - to shut down a meaningful conversation about it?

GLENN GREENWALD, "THE INTERCEPT" FOUNDING EDITOR: The only time, I think, that the media praised Donald Trump was almost one year ago today when he bombed an airfield in Syria in response to what had been alleged at the time was a chemical attack by the Assad regime.

People who hate Donald Trump and go on air every day took a break for 24 hours to proclaim him presidential because that's what US presidents in their eyes do as they just drop bombs on other countries with no declaration of war, no reason why US interest or the US borders are at stake when it happens.

So, I think that's just the ethos in Washington that not only is it just an inherently good and presidential thing to do, to drop bombs on other countries. That's why polls around the world show that the greatest threat to world peace in the eyes of the public around the world is the United States.

But also, Adam Smith wrote 300 years ago that the reason people who live in capitals and the elites in countries love to watch their countries bomb other countries is because it gives them a sense of excitement and purpose and kind of this pulsating stimulation. And I think that's a really big part of it.

It doesn't matter whether it will accomplish anything. It just makes us feel strong and powerful and purposeful to do. And so, bombs away.

CARLSON: I think that's right. I mean, I think human nature explains a lot of this. I agree completely. But journalists exist to push back against that. Not necessarily against war, but against a feverish rush toward anything. I mean, our job is to be skeptical and ask real questions. Why is no one doing that and anyone who does is attacked?

GREENWALD: So, just about every name that you mentioned in the media who attacked you for raising questions about whether or not we ought to actually go and bomb another country are all essentially neocons.

The same people who were doing this in 2002 and 2003, saying anyone who asked questions about whether we should actually go to war and remove Saddam Hussein was an admirer of the Saddam Hussein.

They did the same in 2011 when it came time to remove Gaddafi. They said if you're against that war, it means you love Gaddafi and you want to see him slaughter people. It's just the standard tactic.

And what we have now is this kind of union between neocons, who have now once again kind of been embraced by both the establishment wings of the Republican and Democratic Party and the militarists in both parties, people like Lindsey Graham and lots of Democrats who love every single war.

And so, this climate arises that you're just supposed to cheer when it comes time to drop bombs on other countries, not ask whether there's evidence to justify it, not ask whether it will do any good, not ask whether it will kill any civilians.

And if you do ask those questions, it means you're on the side of America's enemies. It's an incredibly authoritarian tactic that gets used to suppress debate.

CARLSON: Yeah, it's poison. I agree. Glenn Greenwald, thank you as always.

GREENWALD: Good to be with you.

CARLSON: Richard Goodstein is an attorney who advised both of Hillary Clinton's campaigns and he supports strikes on Syria. Richard joins us tonight.

So, look, it seems to me, no matter what conclusion you reach, the first question for everybody ought to be the same, which is how is this in America's strategic interest. And I haven't met a single person who could answer it or is even willing to try. That's a problem, wouldn't you say?

RICHARD GOODSTEIN, FORMER HILLARY CLINTON ADVISER: It would be if there really was no answer.

I did see your interview with Sen. Wicker last night. You asked the question, how do even know Assad was behind this?

CARLSON: Right.

GOODSTEIN: Because Gen. Mattis basically said we weren't sure. But what we know is that a UN Commission saw links between sarin gas that we know was used and had the hallmarks of what the -

CARLSON: Sure. Look, I'm totally open-minded. I'm not here flacking for Assad. My God! I just want to be certain that we are acting on the basis of verifiable information. And in the case of this last weekend's attack with the chlorine gas, let's just stop lying, there is no way that we could know in 48 hours, 24 hours when the cable news shows start pushing for war that Assad was behind this. So, let's stop lying. That's my only point.

GOODSTEIN: Well, I'm not sure who it is - look, it had all the hallmarks of something that we know Assad did. He was destroying towns willy-nilly.

And the notion that somehow the rebels would kill their own women and children and have them foaming at the mouth and so forth to make a point for CNN or Fox, that seems a bit much, right?

But I think what we're trying to do is -

CARLSON: Really, it's a bit much? OK. So, the first sarin gas attack took place within a week of the Trump administration saying we're no longer going to try to remove Assad from power. That happened. Bam, we went right back to the original policy.

This attack took place less than a week after the Trump people said we are going to pull our troops out.

GOODSTEIN: Right.

CARLSON: So, look, I don't know who did it. I'm not accusing anybody. I'm merely saying there's clearly questions that we need to be asking about this. And anyone who does, I'm a living example of this, is shouted down and called a poodle of Putin. Like, that's insane.

GOODSTEIN: I wish I took as much pleasure from my critics coming after me as you do incidentally. So, I applaud you for feeling the umbrage that you do.

CARLSON: I'm attacked all the time. I don't care. I care about when and where we commit American troops. I have a son who is 21. This is not a joke.

GOODSTEIN: Right. So, it's not a question, frankly, of committing troops. Sure, there will be troops. We're talking about degrading their air force, degrading their helicopters, doing something frankly that we didn't do.

CARLSON: What does degrading mean?

GOODSTEIN: It means basically have so many -

CARLSON: Killing people. Let's not use euphemisms here.

GOODSTEIN: Fine. Let's blow up airplanes and helicopters. If there are people in it, so be it. They made their choice to align with Assad and these are the very people who we've seen are dropping - I think we actually have had photographic evidence, dropping chlorine bombs on civilian populations.

So, do I feel badly about that? No. Do I think it's something United States should be doing? Yes.

CARLSON: But hold on. What's the goal? Just let's be really clear We take Assad out, and don't tell me that's not the plan. When you wage war against a government, you're not rooting for its continuation.

GOODSTEIN: No.

CARLSON: Who runs Syria? And I'm saying I don't know actually if taking him out is the objective. And I agree with you. Just continue the war, kill more people.

GOODSTEIN: I think the objective is so that Assad knows that his dropping chlorine gas on people is something where he's going to pay a price. And he has did it.

And I think we have to establish whether he did it or not. And the fact is it shouldn't be a feel-good exercise like it was last year. When Trump was basically talking about that great piece of chocolate cake with Xi, the time he was dropping bombs on those runways, that was a feel-good exercise.

If we're going to do something, we should do something, so that Assad can't do it as easily.

CARLSON: But we don't that he did do it.

GOODSTEIN: I agree.

CARLSON: Does it bother you when there's universal consensus on the left and among established Republicans that we just know, and like stop asking questions, let's just go ahead and do this for reasons that we can't fully explain, we can't tell you how it's going to make you richer or safer or happier, but just shut up and do it anyway? Does it bother you?

GOODSTEIN: Well, it will make us better because we think we need to go after war crimes. The question is whether Assad did it. It has all the hallmarks of Assad. I don't blame people for concluding it did.

Do we need to establish with some certainty that it was Assad? Yes, we should probably do that.

CARLSON: So, every time a government does something appalling or kill civilians, we need to bomb them.

GOODSTEIN: No.

CARLSON: No. OK, right.

GOODSTEIN: We can't address every war crime. But those that we can address, yes, I think we should.

CARLSON: Just so we can.

GOODSTEIN: Plenty more. I grant you.

CARLSON: Yes. All right. Richard, thank you.

GOODSTEIN: My pleasure.

CARLSON: My head is spinning.

One of the Internet's top prostitution sites just shut down and feminists are delighted. Wait, what? No, they're furious. It's getting confusing in feminist world. So, we're going to explain it to you. Is prostitution pro-women? Or is it the exploitation of women? We'll get the new line on that. Next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: The site backpage.com - it's a classified ad site - has been shut down and several top officials who work there have got in trouble. They've been indicted over allegations that that site facilitated prostitution and child sex trafficking.

You would think feminists would be happy about this, and some are. But others are outraged by it.

Women's March tweeted, "The shutting down of Backpage is an absolute crisis for sex workers. That's the new term for prostitutes who rely on that site to safely get in touch with clients. Sex workers' rights are women's rights.

Amy Peikoff is a talk show host and a feminist who supports keeping Backpage up and she joins us tonight. Amy, great to see you.

AMY PEIKOFF, TALK SHOW HOST AND FEMINIST: Hi, Tucker. Thanks for having me back again.

CARLSON: So, I know that you're a libertarian. I don't agree with you, but I certainly respect it. I think it's an intellectually coherent way to look at the world.

PEIKOFF: But I also know you are a feminist. And they seem at odds with each other.

So, the libertarian side of you would say, people have a right to enter into voluntary contracts. Prostitution falls under that heading. It's fine.

But the feminist part of you can't really believe that prostitution is empowering to women because it's the opposite of that.

PEIKOFF: Right. But here's the thing, we're talking about government shutting down a website. And regardless of what you and I, Tucker, think ethically about prostitution and other types of sex work, the question to ask is whether it violates anyone's rights.

And we need to, in order to empower women, leave all choices up to them in terms of how to conduct their own personal sex lives and everything else.

CARLSON: Right. That's the libertarian side. And I get that. I mean, again, I don't fully agree with it, but I think it's a reasonable thing to say.

But the feminist position has nothing to do with that. The feminist position is about empowerment and dignity and not objectifying women, reducing them to their physical appearance, which is, of course, what prostitution does. It degrades women completely.

PEIKOFF: My version - I mean, insofar as I consider myself a feminist, I consider myself a feminist in terms of protecting women's rights. So, whenever there's an actual threat to women's rights, I'm going to be there and argue against whatever it is and say that we need to take some action accordingly.

But insofar as this website was just facilitating transactions having to do with prostitution or other types of sex work, then there's no rights violation and you need to leave the choice up to the women.

We're not going to - it's not the American way to force a particular type of lifestyle choice on someone just because you disagree with it from your own ethical perspective. We need to back up and look at the perspective of the individual rights.

CARLSON: Right. But that doesn't mean that all "lifestyle choices" are the same. And I don't know why a feminist group like Women's March would describe as prostitutes as "sex workers."

Many of them are really young. They are being pimped out by older men and sleeping with creepy - I mean, the whole thing is like disgusting actually.

PEIKOFF: But that problem would be only worse. That problem would be only worse, as I understand it, if there are not online opportunities for these women.

And, Tucker, there are two further kind of troubling implications of something like this, shutting down a site like backpage.com. One is that is in conjunction with a couple of pieces of legislation that are also troubling, designed to remove content about sex off of the Internet.

And I myself, I think that sex is a good thing. I don't think we should be shutting down content on the Internet. And there's been a lot of preemptive removing of content from Reddit and other sites because of this.

And the second thing is that I think this is ominous in terms of other types of websites and tech companies coming under government control in the future.

I mean, we just saw Zuckerberg in front of Congress today and you think, oh, well, right now, it's just a prostitution and sex trafficking website, but next it's going to be Tinder because people are using that to hook up and it's sex and maybe we can get away with controlling that or shutting that down.

CARLSON: Yes. I guess I used to feel that way.

PEIKOFF: And then, it will be Facebook and Twitter. And this is the problem, Tucker.

CARLSON: And I literally can't wait for that day, to be honest with you.

PEIKOFF: But today's websites, Tucker, they are not only the method of distributing content, including all of the content that is necessary to change the culture for the better, they also collect information about users.

So, it's a very different type of media.

CARLSON: I'm aware of it. But let me just ask you - hold on.

PEIKOFF: We have to be very careful about putting that under government control because I think you would agree with me -

CARLSON: I think you think the government is more sinister, I would not agree with you. I agree with you ten years ago back when I was a mindless libertarian who thought that government was the greatest threat to our freedom. But government is elected.

PEIKOFF: OK. So, we do not want to end up in Orwell's 1984. We do not want to end up in Orwell's 1984. And if you think that information is troubling in the hands of somebody who wants to make money, think of it in the hands of government.

CARLSON: Which is elected, unlike Zuckerberg. But, Amy, thank you. It's always nice to have you here. I like smart guests and you are.

PEIKOFF: Thank you.

CARLSON: Mark Zuckerberg, testifying on the Hill, it's a big story. But another tech titan has revealed his vision of the future and it will wreck your night. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Mark Zuckerberg consuming all the headline space recently. And that's lucky for Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey who just revealed his terrifying vision of this country's future.

Last week, Dorsey shared an article he called "great read". The article was published on Medium. It says that there is no bipartisan future for the country. One side must win and totally destroy the other.

The piece describes the country as in a non-violent civil war now. And the only way forward, it says, is to do what California has done.

The piece is pretty explicit about that, import a voter base until elections are mere formalities as they are in California. End all debate. Allow only the left to speak.

In other words, make America a lot more like Twitter, a one-party state where armies of serfs happily serve tech gods like, well, Jack Dorsey. That's the future they are all hoping for. And now you know.

We didn't have anything about sex-crazed pandas tonight, but we're on that because we're journalists. So, stay tuned in the rest of the week for developments. That's it for us.

In New York, right now, Sean Hannity is standing by. Here he is.

END

END

urn:contentItem:5RYS-SB01-JCDN-101M-00000-00Facebook's Zuckerberg to testify before US Congress: source2018-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisWORLDFacebook's Zuckerberg to testify before US Congress: source

NEW YORK: Facebook Inc Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg plans to testify before U.S. Congress, a source briefed on the matter said on Tuesday, as he bows to pressure from lawmakers insisting he explain how 50 million users' data ended up in the hands of a political consultancy. Lawmakers in the United States and Europe are demanding to know more about the company's privacy practices after a whistleblower said consultancy Cambridge Analytica improperly accessed data to target U.S. and British voters in close-run elections. Facebook said on Tuesday the company had received invitations to testify before Congress and that they were talking to legislators.

House Energy and Commerce Committee spokeswoman Elena Hernandez said "The committee is continuing to work with Facebook to determine a day and time for Mr. Zuckerberg to testify". On the same day, Zuckerberg turned down British lawmakers' invitations to explain to a British parliamentary committee what went wrong. The company said it would instead send one of his deputies, suggesting that Chief Technology Officer Mike Schroepfer or Chief Product Officer Chris Cox had the expertise to answer questions on the complex subject. The head of the committee called Zuckerberg's decision "astonishing" and urged him to think again. Facebook shares closed down 4.9 percent on Tuesday and have fallen almost 18 percent since March 16, when Facebook first acknowledged that user data had been improperly channeled to Cambridge Analytica, which was hired by Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign. The privacy breach has raised investor concerns that any failure by big tech companies to protect privacy could deter advertisers and lead to tougher regulation. Christopher Wylie, the whistleblower who once worked at Cambridge Analytica, said on Monday that Canadian company AggregateIQ had developed the software that used the algorithms from the Facebook data to target Republican voters in the 2016 U.S. election. AggregateIQ did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Wylie's remarks. Cambridge Analytica said it had not shared any of the Facebook profile data with AggregateIQ. Cambridge Analytica said last Monday it did not use Facebook data in Trump's campaign, and that it had deleted all Facebook data it obtained from a third-party app in 2014 after learning the information did not adhere to data protection rules. In full-page advertisements in British and U.S. newspapers this week Zuckerberg said the app built by a university researcher "leaked Facebook data of millions of people in 2014". He apologized last week for the mistakes the company had made and promised to restrict developers' access to user information as part of a plan to protect privacy. The U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee said on Monday it had invited Zuckerberg, as well as the CEOs of Alphabet Inc and Twitter Inc to testify at an April 10 hearing on data privacy. The U.S. House Energy and Commerce Committee and U.S. Senate Commerce Committee had already formally asked Zuckerberg to appear at a congressional hearing. The U.S. Federal Trade Commission took the unusual step of announcing on Monday that it had opened an investigation into the company - which it generally only does in cases of great public interest - citing media reports that raise what it called "substantial concerns about the privacy practices of Facebook." (Writing by Susan Thomas; Editing by James Dalgleish) - Reuters/zl

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y79-RMG1-JBV1-X35J-00000-00Facebook's Zuckerberg visits Brussels in EU lobbying push2020-02-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisFacebook's Zuckerberg visits Brussels in EU lobbying pushBrussels, Feb 17 2020

Facebook head Mark Zuckerberg was expected in Brussels on Monday to lobby top European officials who have become the world's toughest enforcers on regulating big tech.

The founder of the world's biggest social network, which also owns Instagram and Whatsapp, comes to EU headquarters just as Brussels is set to unveil a highly anticipated strategy to regulate artificial intelligence.

His visit comes on the heels of similar meetings by Google boss Sundar Pichai, who in January called on Brussels to tread carefully in regulating AI.

An EU spokesman on Monday said Zuckerberg would discuss the "digital agenda" with European Commission Executive Vice President Margrethe Vestager and Commissioner Thierry Breton.

European Commission Vice President Vera Jourova meanwhile "intends to raise issues related to the protection of democracy and fundamental rights, free and fair elections, the fight against disinformation, including the transparency of political advertising," the spokesman added.

In an editorial ahead of the visit, Zuckerberg wrote that his company now firmly backed deeper regulation for big tech, a change of heart that came after the Cambridge Analytica data scandal.

"I don't think private companies should make so many decisions alone when they touch on fundamental democratic values," he said in the Financial Times.

In a statement in January, Facebook said Zuckerberg would "discuss a framework for new rules and regulation for the internet."

Facebook is currently fighting several probes with European data protection agencies and Brussels is looking more deeply into possible anti-trust problems on data use.

The EU's proposal on AI on Wednesday is expected to pursue a "risk-based" approach to assessing machine learning similar to how Europe approaches food safety concerns, such as GMOs and certain chemicals.

The EU was expected to back away from a ban on facial recognition technology, instead asking companies and European authorities to think hard before deploying it.

FACEBOOK

GOOGLE

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X62-NCW1-DYRV-41JH-00000-00Facebook's Zuckerberg, Warren exchange 'fighting' words2019-10-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. B009Facebook's Zuckerberg, Warren exchange 'fighting' wordsCraig Timberg

1) Warren 2) Zuckerberg

Facebook Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg told employees that the company was ready to "go to the mat and . fight" if Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a leading Democratic presidential candidate, follows through on her vow to try to break up major technology firms, according to a leaked recording of his remarks published Tuesday. "If she gets elected president, then I would bet that we will have a legal challenge, and I would bet that we will win the legal challenge. And does that still suck for us?

Yeah," Zuckerberg said in a July meeting with employees, a transcript of which was published Tuesday by technology news site The Verge. He added, "I don't want to have a major lawsuit against our own government. I mean, that's not the position that you want to be in when you're, you know, I mean . it's like, we care about our country and want to work with our government and do good things. But look, at the end of the day, if someone's going to try to threaten something that existential, you go to the mat and you fight." Warren, D-Mass., soon responded over Twitter, "What would really 'suck' is if we don't fix a corrupt system that lets giant companies like Facebook engage in illegal anticompetitive practices, stomp on consumer privacy rights, and repeatedly fumble their responsibility to protect our democracy." The unusually direct exchange between a presidential candidate and a major corporate leader underscored the heightened political stakes for Silicon Valley ahead of the 2020 election. While many technology leaders have been visibly uneasy with President Trump - who attacks the industry routinely over its alleged bias against conservatives and other issues - there also is discomfort with the calls by Warren and other Democrats to regulate technology firms more aggressively than in the past. The most alarming proposal to technology leaders is the call by Warren and some other liberals to dismantle major companies such as Google, Amazon and Facebook for alleged antitrust violations. Chris Hughes, who co-founded Facebook with Zuckerberg, has been among those calling for a breakup of the company on the grounds that it has grown too powerful. Facebook dominates much of social media worldwide through its namesake platform as well Instagram and WhatsApp, both of which Facebook acquired when they were smaller but up-and-coming potential rivals. Zuckerberg said in the same meeting with employees that Facebook is experimenting with a potential alternative to Chinese-owned TikTok, which has grown popular among teens and young adults for its short videos. The Facebook alternative, called Lasso, is being tested in Mexico because, Zuckerberg said, TikTok is not yet popular there. He also said that Facebook was working with government regulators on the company's controversial plan to introduce a new online currency called Libra. After Zuckerberg's comments were published Tuesday, Warren took advantage of the news moment to tout her plan, "How We Can Break Up Big Tech," linking to it in a tweet saying, "I'm not afraid to hold Big Tech companies like Facebook, Google, and Amazon accountable. It's time to #BreakUpBigTech." Facebook spokesman Andy Stone declined to elaborate on Zuckerberg's comments or respond to those from Warren. Hours after the Verge story was published, Zuckerberg linked to it on his Facebook page saying, "even though it was meant to be internal rather than public, now that it's out there, you can check it out if you're interested in seeing an unfiltered version of what I'm thinking and telling employees on a bunch of topics like social responsibility, breaking up tech companies, Libra, neural computing interfaces, and doing the right thing over the long term."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WDR-B6Y1-F03R-N2D6-00000-00Facebook takes another completely unnecessary shot at Apple's business model2019-06-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisFacebook takes another completely unnecessary shot at Apple's business modelAndy Meek

Jun 24, 2019( Boy Genius Report: http://bgr.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook and Apple have been taking thinly veiled shots at each other over the last few years, the cadence of which really picked up in the wake of Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal and the ensuing heap of troubles that followed in its wake. Suffice it to say, the biggest social networking company in the world finds itself fighting against headwinds today that include an enormous amount of mistrust, with even its CEO recently joking[1] the company doesn't exactly have the best record when it comes to privacy.

Nevertheless, for some reason, a top Facebook executive speaking at an event in Berlin on Monday thought it would be worthwhile to amp up the continuing tension[2] between the social network and Apple by launching a fresh broadside against the iPhone maker, of course without calling it out by name. These comments come at a time when Facebook is diving into a major cryptocurrency project and trying to bundle together its myriad messaging services while also avoiding regulation from lawmakers that increasingly have had enough of its mishaps. Image Source: LODI Franck/SIPA/Shutterstock Noting that Facebook is 'free' and meant for everyone, the company's head of global affairs Nick Clegg then went on to rant that 'Some other big tech companies make their money by selling expensive hardware or subscription services, or in some cases both, to consumers in developed, wealthier economies. They are an exclusive club, available only to aspirant consumers with the means to buy high-value hardware and services.' There's no exclusivity or 'VIP access' at the company, Clegg continued. Its services 'are as accessible to students in Guatemala, cattle farmers in the Midwest United States, office workers in Mumbai, tech startups in Nairobi, or taxi drivers in Berlin. More than 2 billion people use our platforms — because they can.' Of course, some of you will no doubt shoot back — Millions of peoples' personal data has been taken advantage of over and over by Facebook. Because it can. Apple CEO Tim Cook, for his part, has done the same in recent weeks, with one of his best lines in his recent commencement address at Stanford University being when he blasted unnamed companies (but the implication being companies like Facebook) as chaos factories. 'It feels a bit crazy that anyone should have to say this, but if you built a chaos factory, you can't dodge responsibility for the chaos,' Cook said. It's unfortunate to see companies make trite arguments to differentiate themselves from the competition and to deflect from their own troubles, but Clegg's argument here is definitely nothing new. Namely, that Apple gets rich by selling super-expensive hardware to users while Facebook is the more populist and better option of the two. Anyone ought to be able to see this straw man from a mile away. Image Source: Photo by Valentin Wolf/imageBROKER/Shutterstock [ 1]: https://www.foxnews.com/tech/zuckerberg-jokes-about-facebooks-privacy-record-in-launching-redesign [ 2]:   https://www.businessinsider.com/facebook-apple-cold-war-nick-clegg-facebook-not-exclusive-2019-6

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5X5V-Y5K1-JDVW-N0XS-00000-00Facebook takes brunt of antitrust pressure; Endeavor postpones IPO2019-09-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisMARKETWEEKExclusiveFacebook takes brunt of antitrust pressure; Endeavor postpones IPOJoseph Williams

During the week ended Sept. 27, Facebook was in the hot seat as lawmakers weighed antitrust and privacy concerns. Meanwhile, Hollywood talent agency Endeavor postponed its IPO, citing market conditions.

Regulatory concerns surrounding antitrust issues and trade relations with China continued to weigh on tech and media stocks for the week ending Sept. 27, with Facebook Inc. in the hot seat.

Lawmakers on Sept. 24 debated antitrust concerns during a Senate subcommittee hearing to determine a balance between over-enforcement and under-enforcement of tech mergers. Some speaking before the Senate Subcommittee on Antitrust, Competition Policy and Consumer Rights argued that tech M&A is crucial to innovation, while others argued that much of the M&A from big tech firms such as Facebook removes potential competition from the market. Senators like Josh Hawley, R-Mo., even argued that the U.S. Federal Trade Commission may be unfit to properly assess the impact of certain tech acquisitions.

In February, the FTC announced that it had formed a task force to monitor competition in U.S. technology markets. In July, Facebook disclosed that it was being investigated by the FTC for antitrust concerns, shortly after it agreed to pay a $5 billion fine to settle FTC-documented privacy violations. Politicians recently have even proposed unwinding previously approved Facebook acquisitions.

Not helping investor sentiment, CNBC on Sept. 26 published results of a survey of senior-level technology executives, showing that Facebook would be the company most likely to face antitrust punitive action from the government's antitrust review. Snap Inc. CEO Evan Spiegel also confirmed that his company has been internally documenting anti-competitive activity from Facebook.

Facebook is also facing regulatory pressure over its cryptocurrency plans, announcing this week that it will delay the launch until all regulatory concerns are addressed.

Facebook shares were off by 4.4% for the week, as of midday trading Sept. 27.

In other news from Washington, D.C., the U.S. government is considering limiting U.S. portfolio investment in Chinese companies, according to a Sept. 27 Bloomberg News report citing unnamed sources. Shares of companies like Tencent Music Entertainment Group, Baidu Inc. and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. were down between 3% and 6% as of midday trading.

Online dating company Match Group Inc. also faced some regulatory heat during the week.

In a lawsuit filed with the U.S. District Court, Northern District of Texas, Dallas division, the FTC claimed that Match.com used fake love interest advertisements to lure hundreds of thousands of consumers into buying paid subscriptions, alleging that Match unfairly exposed consumers to the risk of fraud and engaged in other allegedly deceptive and unfair practices.

Match Group responded in a Sept. 25 statement that the FTC was making "completely meritless allegations supported by consciously misleading figures." Match Group shares were off by 8.8% for the week through midday Sept. 27.

Netflix Inc. shares were also punished during the week. The company recently posted a miss on membership guidance for the June quarter.

One of the more damaging reviews of Netflix came from Barclays, with analyst Kannan Venkateshwar in a Sept. 23 note calling the company "very expensive" compared to its potential market reach.

However, Barclays issued more favorable commentary on the streaming company after its stock was pounded throughout the week.

While "it is tough to make a valuation argument to own Netflix," Venkateshwar said in a Sept. 27 note, "NFLX valuation is a function of its pricing power, churn and optionality from additional revenue sources in the end state. We believe Netflix continues to be in a great position to flex these variables which can add significant value. Therefore, while there is a narrative risk near term for the story muting short term performance, we continue to like NFLX."

While competitive pressure from companies such as The Walt Disney Co. and AT&T Inc. could weigh on Netflix's domestic subscriber base, Netflix still has plenty of growth runway in international markets, and its competitors still face "substantial" execution risks that are not currently being valued, the analyst said.

Netflix showed considerable volatility through the five trading days, falling almost 4% by midweek, but the stock recovered much of those losses, trading down just 0.3% for the week, as of midday trading Sept. 27.

Finally, in IPO news, Hollywood talent agency Endeavor LLC postponed its IPO, citing market conditions.

The Hollywood talent agency planned to offer 15 million shares of class A common stock with a price range between $26 to $27 per share, which is below the $30 to $32 range the company set last week.

"Endeavor will continue to evaluate the timing for the proposed offering," the company said in a statement.

urn:contentItem:60FW-YN11-F07F-8336-00000-00Facebook takes EU to court over data pri...2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisNEWSFacebook takes EU to court over data pri...

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices....

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific k...

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific key phrases means "handing over unrelated but highly-sensitive data," reports the BBC. The European Commission said it will defend the case in court. Tim Lamb, Facebook's competition lawyer, said that they are cooperating with the commission "and would expect to give them hundreds of thousands of documents". "The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations, including highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information, personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees". Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC), which looks into big tech companies and their data practices, has sent a preliminary decision to Facebook-owned WhatsApp for their submissions and made further progress in three other investigations related to Facebook. Facebook is facing two investigations in the EU to find out if the social network has breached competition laws. --IANS na/ ( 203 Words) 2020-07-28-09:20:07 (IANS)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FV-90S1-DYDW-71RH-00000-00Facebook takes EU to court over data privacy concerns2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisFacebook takes EU to court over data privacy concernsNew Delhi, 2020-07-28 10:02:17

London, July 28 (IANS) Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices.


Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific key phrases means "handing over unrelated but highly-sensitive data," reports the BBC.
The European Commission said it will defend the case in court.
Tim Lamb, Facebook's competition lawyer, said that they are cooperating with the commission "and would expect to give them hundreds of thousands of documents".
"The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations, including highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information, personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees".
Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC), which looks into big tech companies and their data practices, has sent a preliminary decision to Facebook-owned WhatsApp for their submissions and made further progress in three other investigations related to Facebook.
Facebook is facing two investigations in the EU to find out if the social network has breached competition laws.
--IANS

London, July 28 : Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that includ...

London, July 28 : Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific key phrases means "handing over unrelated but highly-sensitive data," reports the BBC. The European Commission said it will defend the case in court. Tim Lamb, Facebook's competition lawyer, said that they are cooperating with the commission "and would expect to give them hundreds of thousands of documents". "The exceptionally broad nature of the commission's requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission's investigations, including highly sensitive personal information such as employees' medical information, personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees". Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC), which looks into big tech companies and their data practices, has sent a preliminary decision to Facebook-owned WhatsApp for their submissions and made further progress in three other investigations related to Facebook. Facebook is facing two investigations in the EU to find out if the social network has breached competition laws. Liked This Article? Be The First To Share it! Tweet Share Share Class Send Send

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FV-5JH1-F07F-82CM-00000-00Facebook takes EU to court over data privacy concerns2020-07-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisNEWSFacebook takes EU to court over data privacy concerns

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said...

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific k...

Facebook has taken the European Union to court over privacy concerns as the anti-competition regulators probe the social network for breaching market practices. Facebook said that accepting the EU demand for internal documents that include 2,500 specific key phrases means “handing over unrelated but highly-sensitive data,” reports the BBC. The European Commission said it will defend the case in court. Tim Lamb, Facebook’s competition lawyer, said that they are cooperating with the commission “and would expect to give them hundreds of thousands of documents”. “The exceptionally broad nature of the commission’s requests means we would be required to turn over predominantly irrelevant documents that have nothing to do with the commission’s investigations, including highly sensitive personal information such as employees’ medical information, personal financial documents, and private information about family members of employees”. Ireland’s Data Protection Commission (DPC), which looks into big tech companies and their data practices, has sent a preliminary decision to Facebook-owned WhatsApp for their submissions and made further progress in three other investigations related to Facebook. Facebook is facing two investigations in the EU to find out if the social network has breached competition laws. If you have an interesting article / experience / case study to share, please get in touch with us at Advertisement

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W3C-W801-JBCN-40BG-00000-00Facebook takes on hate, belatedly and selectively2019-05-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:20ZLexisNexisOPINIONFacebook takes on hate, belatedly and selectivelyJohn Diaz

It's hard to quarrel with Facebook's decision to permanently ban some of the high-profile prolific and incendiary users on its social media site. Who among us would want to defend the bile of Milo Yiannopoulos and his racist slurs, the anti-Semitic rantings of Louis Farrakhan or the ugly conspiracy theories of Infowars host Alex Jones who has threatened journalists and suggested the 2012 slaughter of schoolchildren in Newtown, Conn., was an Obama-orchestrated hoax to promote gun control?

President Trump has suggested the Facebook purge of serial haters was part of a pattern of social media discrimination against conservatives. Trump specifically cited his concern that Paul Joseph Watson, a far-right personality who has served as Infowars editor-at-large and a purveyor of conspiracy theories and doctored videos, was on Facebook's banned list.

Trump has warned "I am continuing to monitor the censorship of AMERICAN CITIZENS on social media platforms. This is the United States of America — and we have what's known as FREEDOM OF SPEECH." He has suggested that the social media's attempt to arbitrate the limits of free speech explains why "Congress wants to get involved — and they should."

First things first: This is not a free-speech issue. Facebook is a private enterprise, and users are free to accept or reject its parameters of acceptable expression. What Americans should be worried about is government interference with free speech.

But this controversy, as with so many others surrounding Facebook — on privacy, on its vulnerability to election meddling, on its suppression of content and exploitation of customer data from legitimate news organizations — is yet another measure of the corrosive effects of its extraordinary market domination.

Chris Hughes, a Facebook co-founder, suggested in a New York Times opinion piece published online last week ("It's Time to Break Up Facebook") that the social media giant should be subject to antitrust enforcement. Among his recommendations was that it should be forced to spin off the popular apps Instagram and WhatsApp and that further acquisitions should be banned for several years.

Hughes also suggested that Congress should create a new agency to regulate tech companies, and one of its charges should be to "create guidelines for acceptable speech" on social media.

"This idea may seem un-American — we would never stand for a government agency censoring speech," Hughes wrote. "But we already have limits on yelling 'fire' in a crowded theater, child pornography, speech intended to provoke violence and false statements to manipulate stock prices. We will have to create similar standards that tech companies can use."

I agree with Hughes on one point: The notion of government censoring speech does seem un-American. It would be precarious to police even if it were not impossibly impractical in the infinite world of cyberspace. The haters who were chased off Facebook and other sites willing to comply with the law would simply find other warrens of wanton waste to inhabit.

The more immediate remedy for Facebook accountability would be to force it to choose: Is it a platform or a publisher?

Facebook has essentially claimed each role, depending on the convenience of the moment.

Here is why it matters:

Under the Communications Decency Act of 1996, a platform is not responsible for the content of its users — in much the way a cell-phone company has no liability for your conversations, no matter how offensive, or Amazon would not presume to control what you read on its Kindle device. This principle was tested in a court ruling that cleared MySpace against a claim from a teen who was sexually assaulted by an adult male who met her on the space.

However, a publisher is responsible for its content, and assumes that role by exerting its authority to select, monitor, edit or delete content — or banish users that violate its terms of service.

So which definition fits Facebook? Is it merely a town square, or a conversation curator?

It has argued both sides.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told a U.S. Senate committee in April 2018 that his company is not a "media company" or publisher that creates content. Yet in other contexts, most notably in legal proceedings, it has argued that it has a traditional newspaper-like function to determine what can and cannot be published. Zuckerberg also told the Senate that, "I agree we are responsible for the content," even if Facebook does not produce it.

So where is this all headed? Even with its most advanced algorithms, Facebook would be hard pressed to cull the haters and purveyors of offensive speech from its 2 billion users globally. Are we headed toward a social media future where Americans separate into their ideological camps, as they have with cable news, right to Fox and left to MSNBC? Is Facebook's banishment of Farrakhan, Jones, Yiannopoulous, Watson and a handful of prominent others just a warning shot or the start of a trend that eventually will reach your Trump-supporting uncle in Idaho or antifa-sympathizing niece in Berkeley?

Facebook's moves came soon after the conservative furor of actor James Wood getting locked out of Twitter for his "abusive behavior." After the Mueller report, the Hollywood star tweeted that "If you try to kill the King, you best not miss" with the hashtag #HangThemAll. The Twitter suspension did seem excessive: the famous Ralph Waldo Emerson quote about not missing a strike on the king is often invoked metaphorically.

"The purposeful & calculated silencing of conservatives by @facebook & the rest of the Big Tech monopoly men should terrify everyone," Donald Trump Jr. tweeted on May 3. "It appears they're taking their censorship campaign to the next level. Ask yourself, how long before they come to purge you? We must fight back."

Nothing Facebook or Twitter could do is as terrifying as government intervention in regulating social media speech. If those social media sites become overly censorious, on the right or the left, there are abundant options to families to share prom photos, birthday greetings or news articles — if we are willing to go there. The same is true if those sites become overly infected with hate.

The cold truth is that many of us are addicted to Facebook, even as we complain about the way it exploits our private information, poisons our democracy, limits our news choices and — depending on one's point of view — bans voices we want to hear.

Perhaps the ultimate solution is not to break up Facebook, but to break up with it. If we dare.

John Diaz is The San Francisco Chronicle's editorial page editor. Email: jdiaz@sfchronicle.comTwitter: @JohnDiazChron
